Turning to how far back retroactive payments should go, it turns on the conduct of the parents.  If there was no blameworthy behaviour, the retroactivity should go to when the custodial parent informs the payor that they are seeking additional support.  Generally there will be a limit of 3 years.  For blameworthy parents, the retroactivity should continue to when the support should have changed and did not, without limit.
As to the amount of a retroactive payment, the court should follow the
Guidelines
, but the court has broad discretion to craft a remedy that would be fair having regard to all the circumstances, including hardship on the payor.
Applying this to the cases...
This was an initial application for child support.  The parents had a shared custody arrangement that thought that meant no child support was payable (see
Contino v Leonelli-Contino
).  The incomes of the parents were relatively equal and due to the shared custody any money going to one household would simply be removed from the other.  Due to the lack of blameworthy conduct and the lack of benefit to the children, no retroactive support was awarded.
The father from whom support was being sought was low income (~$23,000/year) and he was supporting a second family.  Any retroactive award would cause his household hardship.  The access costs for him were also high.  Because of the lack of blameworthy conduct, the hardship a retroactive award would cause, and the fact that the standard of living in the custodial household was higher, no retroactive support was awarded.
In this case, the mother had broached the subject with the father but could not afford a lawyer to fight the case.  She was intimidated by her ex-husband and did not know much about his financial situation as he lived in another city.  The husband had had a huge income increase and held it from her, as well as saying that she should have managed her money better to better provide for their kids and that he was paying all he could afford.  Due to the large amount of blameworthy conduct and the large discrepancy in the amount he was paying and the table amount, the court awarded $100,000 in retroactive support.
As in
Henry
, the parties had very different incomes; the father earned more than $100,000K/year, much more than the mother, and he gave no financial support when the need arose.  The mother said she had not wanted to litigate because of the effect it had had on her daughter the last time they litigated.  The court held that the delay of mother was not unreasonable, and the father had no reasonable grounds on which to believe the level of support he was paying was reasonable, and thus the award granted at trial was upheld.
Abella, dissenting in part, had three issues with the decision of Bastarache.
The presumptive starting date of effective notice: the payor has the information on when their income changes, so it is impractical and unrealistic to expect the recipient to keep tabs on the payor’s income; the date should be when the income changes.
The role of blameworthy conduct: the conduct of the payor should be immaterial; the whole obligation depends on the income increase, conduct of the parties is irrelevant.
The three year cutoff: Abella finds this arbitrary - any cutoff of this type should be found in statute, not created by the courts.
human_ratio:
Retroactive child support orders should no longer be rare or difficult to obtain.
Established the framework for assessing claims where there is a large, undisclosed swing in income.
Can the payor say that they reasonably believed they were discharging their child support obligation?
Children are entitled to support from both parents commensurate with their ability to pay.
Can the payor say that they reasonably believed they were discharging their child support obligation?
This case is sometimes referred to as the "don't-ask-don't-tell" case, as the
Federal Child Support Guidelines
do not require payors to update their income information each year, merely that the paying parent make disclosure at least once a year upon request of recipient parent (
s. 25
).

Case_Name: O'Grady v Sparling
ai_facts: The appellant was charged under a provincial Highway Traffic Act with having care or control of a motor vehicle while intoxicated or under the influence of a drug. The charge was laid under a provincial statute that mirrored a similar charge under the federal Criminal Code, but which carried a less severe penalty. The appellant argued that the provincial legislation was ultra vires (beyond the power of) the province because it encroached on the federal power over criminal law.
ai_issue: Does a provincial statute making it an offence to have care or control of a motor vehicle while intoxicated or under the influence of a drug conflict with or invade the field of federal criminal law, rendering the provincial statute ultra vires the provincial legislature?
ai_decision: The Supreme Court of Canada held that the provincial legislation was intra vires (within the power of) the provincial legislature.
ai_reasons: The Court found that the provincial legislation was regulatory in nature, aimed at highway traffic control and safety, which is a valid provincial objective. Although the provincial offence was similar to the federal criminal offence, it did not have the same 'criminal' purpose (prohibition plus penalty for a public wrong) but rather a regulatory one (ensuring safe driving conditions on provincial highways). The court applied the 'pith and substance' doctrine, determining the true character of the legislation was in relation to highway regulation, a provincial matter. The court also indicated that there was no direct conflict or 'occupying the field' issue because the purposes of the two pieces of legislation, while covering similar conduct, were distinct (criminal vs. regulatory).
ai_ratio: A provincial statute dealing with the regulation of highway traffic and safety, even if it prohibits conduct also prohibited by the Criminal Code, is valid provincial legislation if its true 'pith and substance' is aimed at highway regulation and not the creation of a criminal offence aimed at punishing a public wrong. The provincial power over highway regulation is distinct from the federal power over criminal law.
human_facts:
O'Grady was charged under s. 55(1) of the Manitoba
Highway Traffic Act
(now
s. 188
) which prohibited driving "on a highway without due care and attention or without reasonable consideration for other persons using the highway". The defendant challenged the law, claiming that it was beyond the power of the province because the federal government had "occupied the field" with a similar criminal provision in ss. 191/221 (now
s. 219
) of the
Criminal Code
, which prohibited driving with "wanton or reckless disregard for the lives or safety of other persons".  O'Grady was convicted at trial and an appeal to the Court of Appeal for Manitoba was dismissed.
human_issue:
Are provincial laws relating to negligence with penal consequences criminal law and therefore
ultra vires
the province?
human_reasons:
Judson, writing for the majority, held that "the power of a provincial legislature to enact legislation for the regulation of highway traffic is undoubted".  He reaffirmed the principle that there exists a "general area" or "domain" of criminal law and the two governments can make law on the same matter by creating a distinction between the types of culpability.  He quotes from Kenny's Outlines of Criminal Law:
There are only two states of mind which constitute
mens rea
, and they are intention and recklessness. The difference between recklessness and negligence is the difference between advertence and inadvertence; they are opposed and it is a logical fallacy to suggest that recklessness is a degree of negligence. The common habit of lawyers to qualify the word "negligence" with some moral epithet such as "wicked", "gross", or "culpable" has been most unfortunate since it has inevitably led to great confusion of thought and of principle. It is equally misleading to speak of criminal negligence since this is merely to use an expression to explain itself.
On the facts, Judson found that there was overlap between the laws however "there is no conflict between these provisions in the sense that they are repugnant". The provincial law extended to include "inadvertent negligence" as well as regular negligence. It was enough that “the two pieces of legislation differed both in legislative purpose and legal and practical effect” to justify both of them.
human_ratio:
The distinction between recklessness and negligence is the difference between advertence and inadvertence; recklessness is when an actor does not desire harmful consequences but forsees the possibility and consciously takes the risk.
There must be an operational incompatibility between federal and provincial law to invoke paramountcy.

Case_Name: Canada (Attorney General) v Mossup
ai_facts: An employee, Ms. Mossup, claimed sick leave benefits under a collective agreement for an absence from work allegedly due to stress and anxiety caused by harassment and bullying in the workplace. The employer (Attorney General of Canada) denied the claim, arguing that psychological stress resulting from workplace conditions did not constitute an 'illness' or 'injury' within the meaning of the collective agreement.
ai_issue: Does a psychological condition, such as stress and anxiety, caused by workplace conditions (specifically harassment and bullying), constitute an 'illness' or 'injury' entitling an employee to sick leave benefits under a collective agreement?
ai_decision: Yes. The Supreme Court of Canada dismissed the Attorney General's appeal, upholding the lower court's decision that Ms. Mossup was entitled to sick leave benefits.
ai_reasons: The Court interpreted the terms 'illness' and 'injury' in the collective agreement broadly. It held that these terms are not restricted to physical conditions but can include psychological conditions that are medically supported and prevent an employee from performing their job duties. The focus is on the employee's incapacity to work due to a medically recognized condition, regardless of whether the cause is physical or psychological resulting from workplace stressors. The Court found that the collective agreement language did not exclude psychological conditions caused by the workplace environment.
ai_ratio: Psychological conditions, including stress and anxiety, resulting from workplace harassment or other stressors can constitute an 'illness' or 'injury' for the purpose of qualifying for sick leave benefits under a collective agreement, provided there is medical evidence supporting the condition and its impact on the employee's ability to work.
human_facts: Mossop is a gay man, and his partner's father died.  He applied to take bereavement leave from his job to go to the funeral, but is denied because his partner is neither a "spouse" nor a "common law partner" as they are both required to be of the opposite sex.  He makes a claim to the Canadian Human Rights Commission, but refuses to argue sexual orientation as a ground, and instead will only argue family status, stating that all matters to do with homosexuals are not about sexual orientation by definition.  The case was dismissed in the lower courts.
human_issue:
Can a homosexual man claim discrimination against "family status" with his partner under
s.3 of the
Canadian Human Rights Act
?
human_reasons:
The court is upset with the appellant who refused to deal with the claim on the ground of sexual orientation, which was new at the time.  However, Mossop sticks with family status.  The majority says that you cannot interpret "family status" to include Mossop’s situation unless you also discuss the ground of sexual orientation, and as Mossop refuses to do so he cannot be successful.
La Forest
concurs, but instead looks to the definitions in the Act and tries to figure out what the government meant to protect under "family status".  He determines that this specific field was not intended to be covered.
In the dissent,
L'Heureux-Dubé
says that "family status" should have a very broad interpretation.  She looks to the broader social context of limiting it as the majority does, and further that by looking at the plain meaning given in the statute you are really just taking the majority's opinion of the definition, which is exactly what you try to avoid in human rights issues.  She also suggests that when there are overlapping grounds, you should select the one that will succeed and proceed with that one.
human_ratio:
Only identified grounds can be pursued in a human rights claim.
Definitions in human rights legislation are generally interpreted broadly, but the definition given by Parliament in the statute has a good deal of authority in the court's decision on what falls under the definition and what does not.

Case_Name: British Columbia (Superintendent of Motor Vehicles) v British Columbia (Council of Human Rights) (Re Grismer Estate)
ai_facts: Donald Grismer, who had a visual impairment (hemianopia) resulting from a stroke, had his driver's license cancelled by the Superintendent of Motor Vehicles. The cancellation was based on a general medical standard requiring 20/50 visual acuity and 120 degrees of peripheral vision. Grismer argued he could drive safely using compensatory strategies and that the cancellation was discrimination based on disability under the BC Human Rights Act. The BC Human Rights Council found discrimination, which was upheld by the lower courts.
ai_issue: Did the Superintendent's cancellation of Grismer's driver's license based on a general visual standard, without considering his individual ability to drive safely using compensatory strategies, constitute discrimination on the basis of disability that could not be justified as a bona fide and reasonable requirement?
ai_decision: The Supreme Court of Canada upheld the finding of discrimination. The Superintendent failed to establish that the blanket visual standard was a bona fide and reasonable justification.
ai_reasons: Applying the three-step Meiorin test for bona fide and reasonable justification, the Court found that while the purpose of the standard (highway safety) was rationally connected and the standard was adopted in good faith (steps 1 and 2 met), the Superintendent failed the third step. The standard was not reasonably necessary because it did not allow for individual assessment or accommodation of drivers who could demonstrate safe driving abilities despite not meeting the general standard. There was no evidence that accommodating individuals like Grismer would cause undue hardship.
ai_ratio: A blanket safety standard based on a group characteristic (like a medical condition or disability) is discriminatory if it does not accommodate individual differences to the point of undue hardship. To be a bona fide and reasonable justification, a standard must allow for individual assessment or accommodation where it is possible for an individual, despite not meeting the general rule, to safely perform the essential requirement (driving) through other means, such as compensatory strategies.
human_facts: The Government of British Columbia had a policy stating that it would not issue licenses to people suffering from a condition (homonymous hemianopsia (HH)) which affected eyesight.  The claimant had this condition but had driven flawlessly at work and on public roads using "prism glasses".  Despite this he was refused individual assessment and was not allowed to receive a license and was therefore unable to complete his job.  The British Columbia Human Rights Tribunal allowed Grismer to be individually tested.  Grismer died shortly after this decision.  This was upheld by the British Columbia Supreme Court but overruled by the Court of Appeal.
human_issue: Does an absolute prohibition on licensing people with a visual impairment without the possibility of individual assessment constitute discrimination?
human_reasons:
The court applies the
Meiorin
test, showing that it can be used in scenarios outside of the workplace to determine if discrimination is justified.  This case passes the first part because the purpose of the standard (reasonable safety) is rationally connected to the function (issuing drivers’ licenses).  It also passes the second step because there is no evidence that the standard (no licenses for HH sufferers) was adopted for any reasons other than road safety.  However the case fails the third step as the court finds that the standard (no licenses for HH) is not reasonably necessary for the purpose (reasonable safety).  The blanket prohibition doesn't let people even attempt to show that they can drive safely.
It is clear here that the accommodation would be to allow testing.  In order to succeed the government would have had to prove that to allow testing would result to undue hardship which they failed to do.  Although there are clearly safety and cost concerns involved with testing, the government didn't put in any effort to determine these values, nor did they even look for alternative ways of testing.  The court also says that in general, with the government, costs must be exorbitant to amount to undue hardship, as they are publicly funded and this would be seen as being in the public interest.  As the standard is not rationally necessary for the purpose of reasonable road safety, it amounts to discrimination and must be removed.
human_ratio:
The
Meiorin
test applies to all standards that are thought to be discriminatory, even if they do not occur in a workplace; called bona fide justification tests.
The government will be held to a very high threshold when claiming that the costs of not adopting a standard amount to undue hardship as they are publicly funded and preventing discrimination is in the public interest.

Case_Name: Just v British Columbia
ai_facts: The plaintiff was injured when a boulder rolled onto a highway maintained by the defendant, causing the plaintiff's vehicle to crash. The defendant, the province of British Columbia, had a system for inspecting slopes but did not inspect the particular slope, which was known to be unstable. The plaintiff sued for negligence, alleging failure to adequately inspect and maintain the highway.
ai_issue: Did the provincial government owe a duty of care to highway users in its decisions regarding the inspection and maintenance of highways, and if so, was it liable for negligence for failing to adequately inspect a known unstable slope? Specifically, were decisions about inspection and maintenance policy decisions immune from liability or operational decisions subject to a duty of care?
ai_decision: The Supreme Court of Canada held that the province owed a duty of care in its operational decisions regarding highway inspection and maintenance and was liable for negligence.
ai_reasons: The Court distinguished between policy decisions (high-level, discretionary, generally immune from liability) and operational decisions (implementing policy, subject to a duty of care). Decisions about the system of inspection and maintenance, once the decision to build and maintain the highway was made, were operational. The failure to adequately inspect the known unstable slope constituted a breach of this operational duty of care, resulting in foreseeable harm to the plaintiff.
ai_ratio: A government body responsible for maintaining public infrastructure owes a duty of care to users in its operational decisions regarding inspection and maintenance. While policy decisions (e.g., resource allocation for maintenance) may be immune from negligence claims, the operational execution of maintenance and inspection duties is subject to a standard of reasonableness, and a failure to meet this standard can give rise to liability in negligence.
human_facts:
Heavy snow fall forced Just and his daughter to stop in a line of traffic by a rocky slope on a major highway.  A boulder, which worked loose from the wooded slopes above the highway, came crashing down on the appellant's car, killing the appellant's daughter and causing him very serious injuries.  Just brought an action against the provincial government contending that the government negligently failed to properly maintain the highway.
The Department of Highways had set up a system for inspection and remedial work upon rock slopes.  Inspection and recommendations were made by engineers and the work was effected by a rock scaling crew responsible for performing remedial work throughout the entire province.  The department's practice had been to make visual inspections from the highway unless rock falls or a history of instability in an area indicated a need for the rock engineer to climb the slope.  Numerous informal inspections were carried out by highway personnel as they drove along the road.
The trial judge found that the entire system of inspection and the way it was implemented was a policy matter which did not give rise to liability. No finding was made as to whether or not the system of inspection was reasonable or whether the inspections themselves were properly carried out. The Court of Appeal upheld the finding of the trial judge and Just appealled to the Supreme Court.
human_issue: Is the government under a duty of care to maintain the highways and if so, are they liable if the highways are not sufficiently maintained?
human_reasons:
Cory, writing for the majority, held that the province owes a duty of care, which ordinarily extends to their reasonable maintenance, to those using its highways.  The Department of Highways could readily foresee the risk that harm might befall users of a highway if it were not reasonably maintained.  That maintenance could be found to extend to the prevention of injury from falling rock.
Government agencies may be exempt from the application of the traditional tort law duty of care if an explicit statutory exemption exists or if the decision arose as a result of a policy decision.  Whether or not a decision is characterized as a policy decision or as an operational decision rests on the nature of the decision and not on the identity of the actors.  Generally, decisions concerning budgetary allotments for departments or government agencies should be classified as policy decisions.  A policy decision may be open to challenge on the basis that it is not made in the bona fide exercise of discretion.  If after due consideration it is found that a duty of care is owed by the government agency and no exemption by way of statute or policy decision-making is found to exist, a traditional torts analysis ensues (as per
Anns v Merton London Borough Council
) and the issue of standard of care required of the government agency must next be considered.  The manner and quality of an inspection system, since it was clearly part of the operational aspect of a governmental activity, should be assessed when consideration is given to the standard of care issue.  At this stage, the requisite standard of care must be assessed in light of all the surrounding circumstances including budgetary restraints and the availability of qualified personnel and equipment.
Sopinka, in the dissent, held that the government had the power to carry out the inspections but was under no duty to do so.  Conduct within the limits of this discretion gives rise to no duty of care; conduct outside of these limits may attract a private law duty of care.
A litigant may not attack a policy and it is not appropriate for a Court to pass on it, absent evidence that a policy was adopted for some ulterior motive and not for a municipal purpose.  In order for a private duty to arise, it would have to be shown that the Rockwork Section acted outside its delegated discretion to determine whether to inspect and the manner in which the inspection is to be made.  Policy decisions are immune from review because they usually entail not only a decision to do something but also some call upon the public purse.  The government was acting within its discretion when it decided that inspections should be done and the manner in which they were to be done.  Responsibility for deciding the extent to which the inspection program was to be implemented was delegated to the Rockwork Section.
human_ratio:
The duty of care should apply to a public authority unless there is a valid basis for its exclusion.
Policy decisions – the decision by the government about what acts to perform under a given statute – are exempt from liability; operational decisions – the decision by the government about how to perform those acts once they have been decided - are not exempt from liability.

Case_Name: Machtinger v HOJ Industries Ltd.
ai_facts: The appellants, Machtinger and Lefebvre, were employees of HOJ Industries Ltd. Both were terminated without cause after relatively short periods of employment (Machtinger 23 months, Lefebvre 33 months). Their written employment contracts contained termination clauses specifying a fixed notice period (Machtinger: 2 weeks, Lefebvre: 4 weeks) which was less than what would be considered reasonable notice at common law. The contractual notice periods were also less than the minimum notice required by the Ontario Employment Standards Act (ESA) *at the time of termination* for employees of their tenure, rendering the contractual clauses invalid under the ESA.
ai_issue: If an employment contract contains an express term specifying a period of notice for termination without cause, but that term provides for less notice than the minimum required by the applicable employment standards legislation (thus being void), does this invalid express term displace the implied common law term requiring reasonable notice?
ai_decision: The Supreme Court of Canada held that the invalid contractual termination clause did not displace the implied common law right to reasonable notice. The employees were entitled to reasonable notice at common law.
ai_reasons: The Court reasoned that the minimum notice periods established by employment standards legislation (like the ESA) represent a floor beneath which parties cannot contract. An employer cannot contract out of these minimum standards. If an express term in an employment contract regarding termination provides for less than the statutory minimum notice, that term is void and of no effect.  A void contractual term cannot be used to displace the implied common law term of reasonable notice. If the express term is void, it is as if no agreement was reached on termination notice, and the implied term of reasonable notice at common law applies by default. The common law provides the 'gap filler' when a specific, legally compliant, contractual provision is absent or void.
ai_ratio: Where a termination clause in an employment contract provides for less than the minimum notice period required by the applicable employment standards legislation, that clause is void for failing to comply with the legislation, and the employee is entitled to reasonable notice at common law.
human_facts:
Both appellants began working for HOJ Industries, a car dealer, in 1978, and were discharged in 1985 without cause.  At the time they were dismissed Machtinger was credit manager and rust‑proofing sales manager and Lefebvre was sales manager.  Each had entered into a contract for employment for an indefinite period which contained a clause allowing the respondent to terminate his employment without cause, in Machtinger's case without notice and in Lefebvre's case on two weeks' notice.  Under the provincial
Employment Standards Act
the appellants were entitled to a minimum notice period of four weeks.  After they were dismissed, the respondent paid each of them the equivalent of four weeks' salary.  The appellants brought action for wrongful dismissal and the trial judge found that they were entitled to reasonable notice of termination, and that the period of reasonable notice for Machtinger was 7 months and for Lefebvre, 7½ months, however this was overturned by the Court of Appeal.
human_issue: What should the notice period be in order to terminate employment if notice required in employment contract violates legislated standards?
human_decision: Appeal allowed, lower court judgment restored.
human_reasons:
McLachlin, writing a concurring judgment, examined the legal principles governing the implication of terms.  She identifies three types of implied terms:
terms implied by fact (intention required);
terms implied by law (no intention required); and
terms implied by custom and usage,
and identifies #2 as the type the courts will read into a contract.  Implication of law can be from custom, for business efficiency (what is necessary in a contract), or what is reasonable (from Denning's dissent in
Liverpool City Council v Irwin
).
She finds that the Court of Appeal erred in characterizing a term implied in law as a term implied in fact, which brought in the intentionality of the parties.  Holding that the employer had a legal obligation to provide reasonable notice and that this can only be displaced by an express contrary agreement, the court imposed a reasonable term of notification on HOJ; HOJ industries.

Case_Name: Homex Realty and Development Co. Ltd. v Wyoming (Village)
ai_facts: Homex Realty and Development Co. Ltd. entered into a development agreement with the Village of Wyoming for a subdivision. A dispute arose between the parties regarding servicing costs and completion of works. The Village subsequently passed bylaws preventing further development and refused to issue building permits to Homex, citing the unresolved dispute. Homex sued the Village for damages resulting from the delay and interference with its development plans, arguing the bylaws were invalid. The Village counterclaimed for amounts it alleged Homex owed under the agreement.
ai_issue: Did the Village of Wyoming have the legal authority to pass bylaws and refuse building permits for the improper purpose of compelling Homex to settle a contractual dispute, or were these actions an unlawful use of municipal power?
ai_decision: The Supreme Court of Canada held that the Village's bylaws and refusal to issue permits were unlawful and constituted a breach of the development agreement and unlawful interference with Homex's economic interests. Homex was entitled to damages.
ai_reasons: The Court found that the Village's actions were *ultra vires* (beyond its powers) because the bylaws were passed for an improper purpose – specifically, to gain leverage in a contractual dispute rather than for legitimate planning or regulatory objectives. Municipalities cannot use their regulatory powers to enforce private contractual obligations. The bylaws were deemed invalid, and the refusal to issue permits based on these bylaws was unlawful. This constituted a breach of the agreement and an actionable wrong causing damages to Homex.
ai_ratio: A municipality cannot use its regulatory bylaw-making power or permit-issuing authority for an ulterior or improper purpose, such as compelling a party to settle a contractual dispute. Bylaws or actions taken for such an improper purpose are *ultra vires* and invalid, potentially leading to liability for damages caused by the unlawful interference with a party's rights.
human_facts:
As a condition of registration of a plan of subdivision in the Village of Wyoming, Atkinson, the owner and subdivider of the parcel of land, entered into an agreement with the Village for the installation of municipal services in the subdivision. This agreement, dated January 22, 1968, and registered September 26, 1975, provided in a general way for the owner's providing "all the requirements financial and otherwise, of the Corporation re surfacing of roads, installation of services and drainage". The agreement also prevented the sale of the lands in question until the agreement had been fully carried out, except with the consent of the Village, but the provision did not provide that consent would operate to release Atkinson from his obligation to the Village. Before any services were installed, Homex bought the great majority of the lots on the subdivision with the Village's consent. There was some question as to whether or not Homex had undertaken to assume the obligations of the original subdivider. Nevertheless, when protracted negotiations between the Village and Homex concerning the installation of services proved fruitless, the Village, in April 1976, pursuant to s. 29(3) (now
s. 50(3)
) of the
Planning Act
and without notice to Homex, enacted by-law 7 deeming the lots purchased by Homex not to be a registered plan of subdivision. Homex, in September 1976, made application for judicial review for an order quashing by-law 7 and, while the application was pending, checkerboarded its lots.
In November 1975, Homex and the Village negotiated the installation of services along the only street requiring them. By-law 6, enacted in December 1975, provided that it was the policy of the Village that it would neither assume responsibility for a water pipeline constructed by Homex nor permit its connection to the municipal water supply system. Homex coupled an application in judicial review to quash by-law 6 with the application for an order to quash by-law 7.
human_issue: What qualifies as a "legislative" decision such that no duty of procedural fairness applies?
human_reasons:
Estey, writing for the majority, held that while the passage of By-law 7 had some characteristics of a community interest, it was also clearly the culmination of the dispute between the village and Homex.  As a result he found that the decision was quasi-judicial such as to attract the principle of notice and the doctrine of
audi alteram partem
.  Despite this, however, he held that the conduct of Homex to rid itself of the obligations under the agreement with Atkinson were such that it should be denied a discretionary remedy.  There was also no basis to challenge By-law 6 as it simply stated the facts of the agreement with Atkinson.
Dickson, in the dissent, is quoted:
The courts long ago developed the general proposition that wherever a statute authorizes the interference with property or other rights and is silent as to whether or not the agency in question is required to give notice prior to the intervention in such rights, the courts will "supply the omission of the legislature" and require the agency in question to afford the subject an opportunity of being heard before it proceeds.
He held that an act could not be labelled "legislative" merely for the purpose of dispensing with fairness. It was not particularly important that the function of the municipality was classified as "legislative" or "quasi-judicial", rather, it was necessary to look at the nature of the function and to the facts of each case. The by-law in question was not of wide and general application, but was rather aimed at deliberately limiting the rights of Homex, entitling it to some procedural safeguards - at a minimum, notice of the proposed by-law and the opportunity to be heard.
human_ratio:
In general, the courts have not imposed procedural requirements on the subordinate law-making function.
The facts of each case are key to determining the level of procedural fairness required.

Case_Name: Bell Canada v Canadian Telephone Employees Association
ai_facts: An arbitration board interpreted a clause in the collective agreement between Bell Canada and the Canadian Telephone Employees Association concerning payment for time spent on union business. Bell Canada challenged the award on the grounds that the board exceeded its jurisdiction and rendered a patently unreasonable decision.
ai_issue: Did the arbitration board exceed its jurisdiction or render a patently unreasonable interpretation of the collective agreement, justifying judicial intervention?
ai_decision: The Supreme Court of Canada dismissed Bell Canada's appeal, upholding the arbitration award.
ai_reasons: The Court applied the patently unreasonable standard of review to the arbitration board's interpretation of the collective agreement. It found that the board's interpretation, while potentially arguable, was not patently unreasonable or irrational and was within the board's jurisdiction to interpret the agreement. The Court reiterated the principle of judicial deference to specialized labour tribunals acting within their expertise.
ai_ratio: A court should apply a highly deferential 'patently unreasonable' standard when reviewing a labour arbitration board's interpretation of a collective agreement. An arbitration award based on an interpretation of the collective agreement should not be set aside unless that interpretation is patently unreasonable, even if a court might prefer a different interpretation.
human_facts:
This is an appeal of the decision in
Communications, Energy and Paperworkers Union of Canada v Bell Canada
.  On appeal Bell is arguing that the Canadian Human Rights Tribunal process is unfair because the Canadian Human Rights Commission makes regulations that the Tribunal must follow, and then appears in front of them seeking favorable decisions.  They claim that this constitutes a conflict of interest and a lack of necessary "judicial" independence.
human_issue: Does the Canadian Human Rights Tribunal lack independence and impartiality because of the power of the Canadian Human Rights Commission to issue binding guidelines for them before they appear in front of them?
human_decision: Appeal dismissed, case to proceed to Tribunal.
human_reasons:
The court recognizes that Bell's claims are not without merit, however after consideration they dismiss them.  The court held that Bell did not provide sufficient evidence for their claims and also because they misunderstand impartiality - it does not mean having the freedom to decide a case however one wishes to, being subject to certain binding principles is perfectly legitimate for an impartial judiciary.  Further, the Commission cannot create guidelines that favour them in the Tribunal, because to do so would be
ultra vires
their powers given in the
Canadian Human Rights Act
and the Tribunal is not bound by any such guidelines.  The powers that the Commission has to enact guidelines under
s.27(2)
and
s.27(3)
of the
Act
are constrained as all powers to create subordinate legislation are, and therefore the system is not flawed.
human_ratio:
Having one's decisions bound by enacted guidelines does not affect impartiality.
Agencies cannot enact subordinate legislation outside of their delegated powers.

Case_Name: Catholic Children's Aid Society of Metropolitan Toronto v CM
ai_facts: C.M., a child, was born to parents of different religions (father Sikh, mother Roman Catholic). The child was baptized Roman Catholic. The parents separated and had differing views on the child's religious upbringing. The Catholic Children's Aid Society of Metropolitan Toronto became involved and sought wardship of the child, requesting an order that the child be raised in the Roman Catholic faith. Lower courts made various orders regarding wardship and religion. The case ultimately reached the Supreme Court of Canada to determine the proper approach to deciding a child's religious upbringing in wardship proceedings when parents disagree or the state intervenes.
ai_issue: What is the proper test for a court to apply when determining the religious upbringing of a child in wardship proceedings under child protection legislation, particularly when parents hold different beliefs or disagree, and how does the child's best interests principle apply?
ai_decision: The Supreme Court of Canada allowed the appeal in part, clarifying the principles governing decisions about a child's religious upbringing in wardship proceedings. The court emphasized that the child's best interests are the paramount consideration.
ai_reasons: The court held that the child's best interests, as defined by the relevant provincial child protection legislation, are the governing principle for all decisions concerning the child, including religious upbringing. This principle overrides any conflicting rights or preferences of the parents regarding religion. The court is not bound by parental agreements or past practices regarding religion if they are not in the child's best interests. The court should not make a specific order regarding religious upbringing unless it is demonstrated to be necessary and in the child's best interests, considering factors like the child's background, potential harm from religious conflict or change, and continuity. The court rejected approaches that prioritized parental religious rights or sought to maintain the status quo merely because it existed.

A specific order concerning a child's religious upbringing should only be made if it is determined to be in the child's best interests.
human_facts: The aid society took SM into protection on several occasions and supervised her mother, CM, on parenting skills. On consent, SM was made a ward of the society 1989. Throughout the wardship, the society continued to work with CM and facilitated regular visits with SM, however, bonding between mother and daughter remained minimal. In December 1989, after a second four-month wardship, the society brought a status review application seeking an order of Crown wardship without access for the purposes of adoption. CM opposed the motion and the matter was dealt with sporadically throughout 1991. In February 1992 the Ontario Provincial Court ordered that SM be returned to CM on the basis that court intervention was no longer necessary to protect the child. The judge considered CM capable of acquiring the skill to care for her daughter adequately. The society obtained a stay of the order and unsuccessfully appealed to the Ontario Court (General Division). The Court of Appeal granted a stay of the order for return pending appeal and a motion for the introduction of fresh evidence. The new evidence concerned the consistent and repeated assertions of the child that she regarded her foster family as her real family, that she did not want to see her birth mother and that attempts to implement access visits with CM had become almost impossible because of the child's negative reactions - emotional, psychological and physical.  It allowed the appeal, set aside the order for the return of the child to the mother and ordered that the child be made a Crown ward without access for the purposes of adoption. CM appealed to the Supreme Court.
human_issue: Does the child need continued protection?
human_reasons:
L'Heureux-Dubé, writing for the court, reviewed the case law and determined that when a court is determining whether the wardship should be terminated or continue, the judge should not determine whether an order of wardship should have been made in the previous or earlier hearings, but instead
now
consider whether continuation of the wardship in the current proceedings is in the best interests of the child without overlooking the parents' rights.  The review hearing is not about retrying the original need for a protection order, but rather the court should determine the circumstances of the parents or parent since the last order as it relates to the situation with respect to the child's custody, including their physical, mental and emotional state since that time and also whether there is now a lifestyle, including attitudes of the parent, that warrants the child being returned to the parent or to wardship.
She lays out a two part test:
Does the child continue to need protection and require a court order for protection?
The children's aid society must continue to justify its intervention by showing that a court order is necessary to protect the child in the future.  This does not mean that an absence of proof of a deficiency in the parent's parenting capacity is enough to return the child to the parent.  A court order may be necessary to protect the child from emotional harm which would result in future if the child were taken from its psychological parents.
What is in the best interests of the children?

Case_Name: Edgeworth Construction Ltd. v N.D. Lea & Associates Ltd.
ai_facts: Edgeworth Construction Ltd. (contractor) submitted a bid for a road construction project for the Ministry of Transportation and Highways of British Columbia (MOTH). The bid was based on plans and specifications prepared by N.D. Lea & Associates Ltd. (engineering firm), which bore the firm's seal and the engineer's signature. The plans and specifications contained errors and misrepresentations regarding the nature and quantity of work required, leading to increased costs for Edgeworth. Edgeworth sued N.D. Lea & Associates Ltd. for damages resulting from negligent misrepresentation, despite having no direct contract with the engineering firm.
ai_issue: Did the engineering firm, N.D. Lea & Associates Ltd., owe a duty of care to Edgeworth Construction Ltd., a general contractor who relied on the firm's plans and specifications when bidding on and performing a project for a third party (the government), such that the firm could be held liable for negligent misrepresentation?
ai_decision: Yes, the Supreme Court of Canada held that the engineering firm owed a duty of care to the contractor and could be liable for negligent misrepresentation. The appeal was allowed in part, restoring the part of the trial judgment against N.D. Lea & Associates Ltd.
ai_reasons: The Court applied the principles of negligent misrepresentation. The engineering firm knew or ought to have known that contractors would rely on the plans and specifications to formulate their bids and carry out the work. By affixing their professional seal and signature to the documents, the firm indicated professional responsibility and that the documents were meant to be relied upon by those, like bidding contractors, who would foreseeably use them. The contractors constituted an identifiable class of persons whose reliance was foreseeable and intended. The absence of a direct contractual relationship between the engineering firm and the contractor did not preclude a duty of care for negligent misrepresentation, which extends beyond contractual privity. The affixing of the seal was equivalent to a representation of the accuracy of the information contained in the documents to potential bidders.
ai_ratio: An engineering firm that prepares plans and specifications for a project owner and affixes its professional seal and signature owes a duty of care for negligent misrepresentation to general contractors who foreseeably rely on those documents when bidding on and performing the project, even in the absence of a direct contractual relationship. The professional seal and signature signify responsibility and foreseeable reliance by an identifiable class (bidding contractors).
human_facts: Edgeworth Construction Ltd. was engaged in the business of building roads in British Columbia.  In 1977, it bid on a contract to build a section of highway in the Revelstoke area.  Its bid was successful, and Edgeworth entered into a contract with the province for the work.  Edgeworth alleges that it lost money on the project due to errors in the specifications and construction drawings.  It commenced proceedings for negligent misrepresentation against the engineering firm which prepared those drawings, N.D. Lea & Associates Ltd. as well as the individual engineers who affixed their seals to the drawings.
human_issue: Is the defendent exempt from liability due to the intervention of the Ministry and their liability clause?
human_reasons:
McLachlin, writing for the majority, holds that liability for negligent misrepresentation occurs when a defendant:
makes a representation,
knows it will be relied upon, and
it is relied upon.
When Edgeworth performed the construction it was relying on N.D. Lea, not the provincial government.  Following the provisions in
London Drugs
the court finds there was no express or implied protection of the respondent in the contract.  Further, unlike in
London Drugs
the respondent could have drawn up a contract that protected it from liability.
human_ratio: Employees who are not "powerless" will not benefit from an employer's exemption.

Case_Name: Miglin v Miglin
ai_facts: A husband and wife, sophisticated business people, negotiated a comprehensive separation agreement after the breakdown of their marriage. The agreement, drafted with legal advice, dealt with property division, custody, access, child support, and spousal support. A few years later, the wife applied under the Divorce Act for spousal support, arguing the agreement was no longer valid and should be disregarded due to a material change in circumstances. She claimed her business had failed and her financial situation had worsened considerably since the agreement was signed, while the husband's had improved. The trial judge upheld the agreement; the Court of Appeal overturned this decision, finding the agreement should be given little weight due to the changes. The case reached the Supreme Court of Canada.
ai_issue: What is the appropriate approach for courts to take when asked to set aside or vary a spousal support provision in a separation agreement under the Divorce Act? How much weight should be given to a pre-existing agreement?
ai_decision: The Supreme Court of Canada allowed the appeal, reinstating the trial judge's decision to uphold the agreement, subject to revisiting the child support amount which could impact spousal support.
ai_reasons: The Court established a two-stage process for reviewing separation agreements related to spousal support under the Divorce Act. Stage 1 (Formation): Examine the circumstances surrounding the execution of the agreement. Courts should consider whether the agreement was negotiated fairly, with full financial disclosure, legal advice, and free from duress or undue influence. If the formation is flawed, the court may give the agreement little or no weight. The analysis at this stage is prospective, based on the situation at the time of signing. Stage 2 (Review): If the agreement was validly formed, consider whether, at the time of the application to vary, the agreement still reflects the objectives of the Divorce Act (fair compensation, financial self-sufficiency, equitable sharing of consequences of child care). This stage requires a retrospective analysis. A significant change in circumstances alone is not sufficient to overturn a valid agreement; the change must have been unforeseen or unforeseeable at the time of the agreement *and* have led to a situation that is no longer in substantial compliance with the Act's objectives. The agreement is a key factor but not the only one. In this case, the agreement was validly formed. The alleged changes in circumstances, particularly the wife's business failure, were considered risks inherent in her chosen career path and not necessarily unforeseen or rendering the agreement substantially non-compliant with the Act's objectives, given her business background and the nature of the agreement. The Court emphasized promoting the finality and certainty of private ordering through agreements, especially between sophisticated parties who had legal advice.
ai_ratio: Separation agreements regarding spousal support are entitled to significant weight and respect under the Divorce Act, reflecting the principle of private ordering. Courts should review such agreements using a two-stage approach: first, examine the circumstances of the agreement's formation (fairness, disclosure, legal advice, absence of coercion); second, if validly formed, consider whether, at the time of the application, the agreement remains in substantial compliance with the objectives of the Divorce Act, taking into account unforeseen or unforeseeable changes in circumstances that have led to a situation that diverges significantly from the Act's goals. A material change in circumstances alone is not sufficient to set aside a valid agreement; the change must be significant and unforeseen/unforeseeable, *and* the agreement must no longer be in substantial compliance with the Act's objectives as a result of that change.
human_issue: When should a support agreement be upheld by the courts?
human_decision: Appeal allowed; original support order stands.

Arbour and Bastarache, writing for the majority, stress finality and certainty as key principles in support agreements, citing

Divorce Act

Case_Name: Dobson v Dobson
ai_facts: Cynthia Dobson was in a car accident while 27 weeks pregnant with her son, Ryan. Ryan was born prematurely and suffered injuries attributed to the accident. The father, as Ryan's litigation guardian, sued Cynthia for negligence causing Ryan's prenatal injuries.
ai_issue: Does a pregnant woman owe a duty of care in tort to her fetus such that the child, once born alive, can sue the mother for damages resulting from prenatal injuries caused by the mother's negligence during pregnancy?
ai_decision: The Supreme Court of Canada held that a pregnant woman does not owe a duty of care in tort to her fetus. The appeal was allowed, and the action against the mother was dismissed.
ai_reasons: The Court reasoned that recognizing such a duty of care would represent an unacceptable intrusion into the pregnant woman's autonomy and bodily integrity. Decisions made by a pregnant woman intimately affect the fetus, and imposing a duty would subject virtually every decision she makes during pregnancy to potential legal scrutiny, creating a massive and unprecedented liability. The Court emphasized that creating this type of duty, which involves significant policy considerations balancing the interests of the born child and the autonomy of the mother, is a matter for the legislature, not the courts.
ai_ratio: A pregnant woman does not owe a duty of care in tort to her fetus, and therefore, a child born alive cannot sue its mother in negligence for prenatal injuries caused by the mother's actions or omissions during pregnancy, primarily due to policy concerns regarding maternal autonomy and bodily integrity.
human_facts: Cynthia Dobson was a pregnant woman.  While in the 27th week of pregnancy she was driving her car when her negligent actions caused a car accident.  The fetus was permanently injured, and was born prematurely that day.  Her son, Ryan Dobson, suffered physical and mental injuries, including cerebral palsy.  His grandfather launched a tort claim for damages against his mother.  Ryan was successful at the Court of Appeal, which his mother appealed.
human_issue: Should a mother be liable in tort for damages to her child arising from a prenatal negligent act that allegedly injured the fetus in her womb?
human_reasons:
Cory, writing for the majority, finds that the mother should not be held liable in the situation because of the policy implications.  They employ the
Kamloops
test to determine if a duty of care should be owed.  It has two parts:
Is the relationship between the two parties close enough to create a reasonable duty?
Are there any public policy implications that should negate or limit the scope of the duty?
They find that the first part is satisfied; however the public policy implications negate the duty.  They state that there are two main reasons for this: it would violate the privacy and autonomy of women, and it is impossible to judicially define a reasonable standard of conduct for pregnant women.
McLachlin, in a concurring judgment, states that another main reason why this duty cannot be imposed is that it would violate pregnant women's rights under the
Charter
– specifically liberty and equality.  They would lose their liberty, and not be treated equally with other women in society.
Major, in the dissent, states that in order for the public policy implications to negate the duty they must add new restrictions on what the woman can do.  He says that this is not the case, because she had a duty of care to everyone else on the road, and extending that to the foetus would not change the reasonable standard of her conduct.  He says that this case deals specifically with pregnant women driving automobiles, and if the creation of duty imposed a limitation on her actions that was not there previously then the outcome would be different.  He uses the example with another pregnant woman in the car – if the same outcome occurred, then there is no question that the other woman's foetus could sue her for negligence.  He agrees that the
Kamloops
test applies, but says that the policy implications here do not negate the duty.
human_ratio:
Pregnant women do not owe a duty of care to the foetus in their womb.
The test to determine if a duty of care is owed has two parts:
Is the relationship close enough to create a reasonable duty?
Are there public policy grounds to negate or limit the scope of the duty?
